articles.headline: ‘Afraid to Be a Nurse’: Health Workers Under Attack
articles.snippet: Stigmatized as vectors of contagion in some countries, health care workers have been assaulted, abused and ostracized.
articles.abstract: Stigmatized as vectors of contagion in some countries, health care workers have been assaulted, abused and ostracized.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The senior nurse went on national television to make a plea on behalf of her fellow health care workers: Please stop assaulting us.

articles.headline: In Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine, an Oxford Group Leaps Ahead
articles.snippet: As scientists at the Jenner Institute prepare for mass clinical trials, new tests show their vaccine to be effective in monkeys.
articles.abstract: As scientists at the Jenner Institute prepare for mass clinical trials, new tests show their vaccine to be effective in monkeys.
articles.lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — In the worldwide race for a vaccine to stop the coronavirus, the laboratory sprinting fastest is at Oxford University.

articles.headline: Job or Health? Restarting the Economy Threatens to Worsen Economic Inequality
articles.snippet: The coronavirus recession has exacerbated the racial and income divides in America. Lifting restrictions too soon will make them worse and leave workers with a bleak choice.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus recession has exacerbated the racial and income divides in America. Lifting restrictions too soon will make them worse and leave workers with a bleak choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Efforts to quickly restart economic activity risk further dividing Americans into two major groups along socioeconomic lines: one that has the power to control its exposure to the coronavirus outbreak and another that is forced to choose between potential sickness or financial devastation.

articles.headline: Bankers Rebuke S.B.A. as Loan System Crashes in Flood of Applications
articles.snippet: The government started taking applications Monday for a further $310 billion in emergency funds, and quickly ran into technical problems.
articles.abstract: The government started taking applications Monday for a further $310 billion in emergency funds, and quickly ran into technical problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Minutes after a $310 billion aid program for small companies opened for business on Monday, the online portal for submitting applications crashed. And it kept crashing all day, much to the frustration of bankers around the country who were trying — and failing — to apply on behalf of desperate clients.

articles.headline: Reopening Plans Across U.S. Are Creating Confusing Patchwork
articles.snippet: Several states, including Texas and Florida, have stay-at-home orders expiring this week. “That executive order has done its job to slow the growth of Covid-19,” Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said.
articles.abstract: Several states, including Texas and Florida, have stay-at-home orders expiring this week. “That executive order has done its job to slow the growth of Covid-19,” Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Governors across the country forged ahead Monday with plans to reopen their economies, even as the nation hit a grim milestone of 50,000 deaths from the coronavirus and public health experts warned against lifting stay-at-home orders too quickly.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Manny Fernandez and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Fired in a Pandemic ‘Because We Tried to Start a Union,’ Workers Say
articles.snippet: Employees who were in unions or pushing to join them have been laid off and replaced by nonunionized labor. It’s part of a pattern stretching back decades, experts say.
articles.abstract: Employees who were in unions or pushing to join them have been laid off and replaced by nonunionized labor. It’s part of a pattern stretching back decades, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Truck drivers and warehouse workers at Cort Furniture Rental in New Jersey had spent months trying to unionize in the hopes of securing higher wages and better benefits. By early this year, they thought they were on the cusp of success.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Coronavirus Diplomacy: How China’s Red Cross Serves the Communist Party
articles.snippet: The Red Cross in China seems like any other humanitarian group. But there is one crucial difference: it is funded and directed by the Chinese Communist Party.
articles.abstract: The Red Cross in China seems like any other humanitarian group. But there is one crucial difference: it is funded and directed by the Chinese Communist Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donations flooded in to fight the virus devastating the city of Wuhan, and the ruling Communist Party directed them to a group it could trust: the Chinese Red Cross.
articles.byline: By Javier C. Hernández and Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: China’s Factories Are Back. Its Consumers Aren’t.
articles.snippet: The manufacturing giant is once again turning out steel and cellphones. But job losses and pay cuts have left its people reluctant to spend — a problem the U.S. and Europe may soon face, too.
articles.abstract: The manufacturing giant is once again turning out steel and cellphones. But job losses and pay cuts have left its people reluctant to spend — a problem the U.S. and Europe may soon face, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An unemployed young college graduate has stopped buying new sneakers. A clothing store clerk gave up his gym membership. An events planner, his pay cut by four-fifths, now moonlights as a takeout delivery driver — and can no longer afford to eat out.

articles.headline: Investors Bet Giant Companies Will Dominate After Crisis
articles.snippet: The virus outbreak supercharged a continuing shift in the markets, with a few giant companies now exerting the most influence over the direction of stocks since the tech boom.
articles.abstract: The virus outbreak supercharged a continuing shift in the markets, with a few giant companies now exerting the most influence over the direction of stocks since the tech boom.
articles.lead_paragraph: An economic downturn almost always favors giants like Microsoft, Apple and Amazon, the country’s three most valuable companies. But the demand for their shares has only been amplified by a crisis that seems almost tailor-made for their future success.
